Thanks @ottobackwards ! All looks good to me. +1 merging to main
@patricker @mattyb149 Can we add some optional logging that will output the sql statement text so it will be easier to troubleshoot. Also log the timestamps.
Thanks @kotarot for the work. Tested this PR with nifi-toolkit version 1.11.4, it works!!!

I am currently reviewing this. While the introduction of `SslContextFactory.Server` does help, other changes here need to be considered, and additional regression tests need to be introduced. I am working to bring this to a stable state.

@mattyb149 I went through this pretty closely and I think it looks good. The Probabilistic and Reservoir sampling produces the right distributions over 100k files. Two things I wanted to verify: (1) since the reservoir sampling is in-memory (for good reasons), setting it too high will be problematic? and (2) you've opted to not do these as controller services because that's potentially more complicated than most users would need/want?
@readl1 I can add those, sure.  How about `INFO` level for the timestamps, and `DEBUG` level for SQL Statements?

Sure that works!

On Wed, Aug 26, 2020, 10:14 PM Peter Wicks <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> @readl1 <https://github.com/readl1> I can add those, sure. How about INFO
> level for the timestamps, and DEBUG level for SQL Statements?
>
> â€”

> unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ACHJPBJB4C4YXL2U25FV4FDSCW6RBANCNFSM4EBDBPRA>
> .
>
+1 LGTM

You're right on both counts.  Setting a very large reservoir can cause memory issues but I chose to do it in-memory for performance reasons, figuring that sampling is meant to choose a (potentially much) smaller set of records, and if the total number of sampled records is still very large, the flowfile could be split beforehand and then sampled. It changes the overall behavior of course but I figured most of the use cases are covered by this implementations.
Also I didn't make the sampling strategies controller services (or even separate class files) mostly because I didn't foresee any other usage of them, but they can always be refactored into their own files and/or components if need be.
Merging to main...

1. `./bin/nifi.sh` diagnostics, dump, and stop when it's not running
2. `./bin/nifi.sh` with invalid args

Thoughts?

I'm having trouble running tests on my computer today. If I get them working later today, or you run the code and find issues, let me know :)

@kotarot thanks for your submission. I have opened a [new PR 4498](https://github.com/apache/nifi/pull/4498) which includes these changes but also:

* removes unnecessary test exception handling
* adds regression tests for JKS and PKCS12 keystores with multiple certificates
* updates additional references to the deprecated `SslContextFactory`

The regression tests match empirical testing and verify that a keystore which contains multiple certificates does not prevent the application from starting. 

I am closing this PR.
I also verified that creating a `ListenHTTP` processor with a `RestrictedSSLContextService` using the same multiple certificate keystore works successfully.

Code looks good and tested starting the app with the multiple certs keystore and worked correctly.

Running a build with Java 8 shows a test error which also seems present in the GitHub Actions build:
```

[ERROR]   JettyServerGroovyTest.testShouldStartWithMultipleCertificatePKCS12Keystore Unexpected call of System.exit(1).
[INFO]
[ERROR] Tests run: 24, Failures: 2, Errors: 0, Skipped: 1
```
@alopresto Thank you so much for catching up with it, Andy!

I believe that maybe we should follow the same conventions as `service`
 
* start: 0 only if nifi is started or already running. 
* stop: 0 if nifi is stopped at the end of the command. So still 0 if nifi was not running on the first place. 
* run: exit code returned by `org.apache.nifi.NiFi`
* restart: 0 if nifi is started or already running. 
* status: 0 only if nifi is running. 
* dump: non-zero exit code if nifi was not running
* diagnostics: non-zero exit code if nifi was not running, tools.jar / classes.jar not found etc
* install: 
* stateless

But that will require some changes to `org.apache.nifi.bootstrap.RunNiFi`
I don't see the usefulness of such a method and I am not sure it is worth the big code change, sorry

> I don't see the usefulness of such a method and I am not sure it is worth the big code change, sorry

Hello Marco! Thanks for your time!

In the past I've been use NiFi for some data trasformations and, sometime, some automatical conversions (for example from JSON -> Avro) wasn't compatible with the "empty value filosofy" used inside NiFi. For example: When I have an empty value: what is it? Is it a string? is a number? It could be a "null" values?

This change skips this misunderstanding enabling the user to use programmatically NULL value (inside of expression language)

if you think it's better, I can create an article to expose that!

Kind regards
I think you can maybe send an email in the community list to check whether this is a feature many people need and in case of a favorable result we can go ahead with the PR. Thanks.

Hello @Fabryprog, 
Whatever the outcome of the discussion with the community, I would undersline that you are not actually interested in the null value itself (if I understood correctly) but rather in propagating the type a field which is null for a specific in-transit object
As this effects only older versions, changing the current main does not seems to be a satisfying solution. This review will be abandoned, a different approach is taken.

@markap14 Looks like there are checkstyle errors for unused imports in `FlowController`.

Thanks for this contribution. It might feel like I put a lot of comments/questions that are designed to prevent things from being merged. That's not my intent. We get a lot of submissions which work very well for a specific use case and "scratch your own itch" as it were, and people don't evaluate/aren't aware of a lot of the negative/edge cases which can arise in the many scenarios users deploy NiFi into. If you're not interested in trying to address all the possible combinations and failure scenarios, that's ok. We always appreciate sharing these features with the community, and often suggest hosting the code for the custom processors in your own repository so interested users can build and deploy them locally. To be accepted and bundled as part of the core project, however, we have a (non-legally obligated) responsibility to support and maintain the code, so we have to reach a certain threshold of familiarity and basic behavioral consistency in order to do that. Thanks.
Thanks for the review @alopresto, I'll try to address all the comments as best I can over the next few weeks when I get some time
I'll review this as well.

I've been getting this error since the time I started using the processor after your changes in the build. Can you please check? The details given are all correct at my end. I tried with 2 source systems. I am getting response when I run a query using execute sql processor

FastInfoset-1.2.15.jar                   jaxb-impl-2.3.0.jar                      stax-ex-1.8.jar                          xmpp-extensions-client-0.8.2.jar
istack-commons-runtime-3.0.7.jar         jaxb-runtime-2.3.1.jar                   txw2-2.3.1.jar                           xmpp-extensions-common-0.8.2.jar
javax.activation-api-1.2.0.jar           nifi-utils-1.13.0-SNAPSHOT.jar           xmpp-addr-0.8.2.jar
jaxb-api-2.3.0.jar                       nifi-xmpp-processors-1.13.0-SNAPSHOT.jar xmpp-core-client-0.8.2.jar
jaxb-core-2.3.0.jar                      precis-1.0.0.jar                         xmpp-core-common-0.8.2.jar


Those all show up in the nar content.  We need to ensure our LICENSE/NOTICE exists within the nar to reflect these binary dependencies as appropriate.  So far the rocks/xmpp bits are just MIT and I dont yet see any copyright bits.  But these need to be in the LICENSE.  I've not checked other items yet to esnure they're ok.  But that needs to be done.  We cannot include the nar by default in the overall nifi assembly as we're very space constrained just now.  But easy for folks to add the nar as needed once this makes it in.

@MikeThomsen I tested this against Atlas, validated it's using the SRV records, and ran all the ITs. Minor request while we're making the change, could we drop the build profiles since we can just set `mongo.driver.version`? It seems like it'll be annoying to maintaining (e.g., we have 3.4.x, .6.x, .8.x and .12.x but not .10 now).

So far, from my perspective things look good @mattyb149 . One thing that I noticed, though, is that if you have processors that are stopped, the headless mode will go ahead and run those. Which makes sense because there's no way to start/stop the processors. But if the processor depends on a controller service, those controller services don't get automatically enabled. Do you think it makes sense to go ahead and enable Controller Services before starting the processors?
Yeah makes sense for headless to enable the controller services since there's no UI to enable them. Then any dependent processors can start as you mentioned. Will add
This is pretty straight forward, +1 from me.  You need a committer +1 to go with it
Also, thank you for the contribution!

* mongo:3.6
* mongo:4
